sec.title: Identity & Control d'Harrison White en français
sec.p: Le 7 avril 2011, la liste de distribution BMS-RC33 a diffusé une présentation de la version française du livre Identity and Control: A Structural Theory of Social Action, par Harrison White (1992, Princeton: Princeton University Press). Cette présentation reprise ci-dessous a été faite par un des traducteurs du livre, notre collègue et membre du Comité scientifique du BMS, Michel Grossetti. Son travail avec Frédéric Godat a donné lieu à Identité et contrôle – Une théorie de l'émergence des formations sociales (2011, Paris: Editions de l'Ecole des hautes études en sciences sociales, ISBN 978 2 7132 2271 9, 493 pp.).

“Comment émergent des formations sociales complexes ? Comment construisons-nous nos identités ? Cette version revisitée et traduite donne accès pour la première fois en France à l'ouvrage majeur d'H. White, figure centrale de la théorie des réseaux sociaux.”

“Harrison White est cité comme l’un des grands théoriciens contemporains des sciences sociales. Identity and Control, initialement publié en 1992, offre un cadre d’analyse pour étudier le déploiement des dynamiques sociales et de l’action humaine. Les deux concepts d’identité et de contrôle fournissent des outils non conventionnels, avec un vocabulaire propre et une série de cas concrets, pour penser les dynamiques de formations sociales très diverses. H. White utilise fréquemment des analogies avec les sciences de la nature (chimie, cybernétique, mathématiques, physique) ; il s'appuie aussi sur de nombreux exemples pris dans les sciences sociales américaines et européennes (Granovetter, Bourdieu, Luhmann, Boltanski…), et dans la vie quotidienne (les rencontres amoureuses, la vie universitaire américaine, la naissance du rock…).”

“Frédéric Godart et Michel Grossetti proposent ici une traduction d’une version entièrement révisée. Le cheminement qu’ils proposent à travers les principaux concepts d’Identity and Control dégage les innovations théoriques et méthodologiques et permet de s'approprier des notions clés sur le monde social dans lequel nous vivons.”

Les huit chapitres du livre sont : 1. Des identités à la recherche de contrôle (43-64) ; 2. Réseaux et récits (65-110) ; 3. Trois disciplines (111-164) ; 4. Styles (165-228) ; 5. Institutions et rhétoriques (229-284) ; 6. Régimes de contrôle (285-350) ; 7. Générer de l'action (351-410) ; 8. Vue d'ensemble et contextes (411-458).

sec.title: Sociological Methodology, Volume 40
sec.p: Tim Futing Liao (ed.) Sociological Methodology, Volume 40 (2010, American Sociological Association, ISBN 978 1 4443 3966 6, 393 pp.), includes eight chapters: 1. Jacques-Antoine Gauthier, Eric D. Widmer, Philipp Bucher and Cédric Notredame, Multichannel Sequence Analysis Applied to Social Science Date (1-38); 2. Anna Manzoni, Jeroen K. Vermunt, Ruud Luijkx and Ruud Muffels, Memory Bias in Retrospectively Collected Employment Careers: A Model-based Approach to Correct for Measurement Error (39-73); 3. Judea Pearl, The Foundations of Causal Inference (75-149); 4. Weihua An, Bayesian Propensity Score Estimators: Incorporating Uncertainties in Propensity Scores into Causal Inference (151-189); 5. Ke-Hai Yuan and Peter M. Bentler, Finite Normal Mixture SEM Analysis by Fitting Multiple Conventional SEM Models (191-245); 6. Olga Lukočienė, Roberta Varriale and Jeroen K. Vermunt, The Simultaneous Decision(s) about the Number of Lower- and Higher-level Classes in Multilevel Latent Class Analysis (247-283); 7. Krista J. Gile and Mark S. Handcock, Respondent-driven Sampling: An Assessment of Current Methodology (285-327); 8. Christian Steglich, Tom A. B. Snijders and Michael Pearson, Dynamic Networks and Behavior: Separating Selection from Influence (329-393). Since the latter two chapters could be of particular interest to BMS readers, we provide the abstracts below.

Gile and Handcock: Respondent-driven sampling (RDS) employs a variant of a link-tracing network sampling strategy to collect data from hard-to-reach populations. By tracing the links in the underlying social network, the process exploits the social structure to expand the sample and reduce its dependence on the initial (convenience) sample. The current estimators of population averages make strong assumptions to treat the data as a probability sample. We evaluate three critical sensitivities of the estimators: (1) to bias induced by the initial sample, (2) to uncontrollable features of respondent behavior, and (3) to the without-replacement structure of sampling. Our analysis indicates: (1) that the convenience sample of seeds can induce bias, and the number of sample waves typically used in RDS is likely insufficient for the type of nodal mixing required to obtain the reputed asymptotic unbiasedness; (2) that preferential referral behavior by respondents leads to bias; (3) that when a substantial fraction of the target population is sampled, the current estimators can have substantial bias. This paper sounds a cautionary note for the users of RDS. While current RDS methodology is powerful and clever, the favorable statistical properties claimed for the current estimates are shown to be heavily dependent on often-unrealistic assumptions. We recommend ways to improve the methodology.

Steglich, Snijders and Pearson: A recurrent problem in the analysis of behavioral dynamics, given a simultaneously evolving social network, is the difficulty of separating the effects of partner selection from the effects of social influence. Because misattribution of selection effects to social influence, or vice versa, suggests wrong conclusions about the social mechanisms underlying the observed dynamics, special diligence in data analysis is advisable. While a dependable and valid method would benefit several research areas, according to the best of our knowledge, it has been lacking in the extant literature. In this paper, we present a recently developed family of statistical models that enables researchers to separate the two effects in a statistically adequate manner. To illustrate our method, we investigate the roles of homophile selection and peer influence mechanisms in the joint dynamics of friendship formation and substance use among adolescents. Making use of a three-wave panel measured in the years 1995-1997 at a school in Scotland, we are able to assess the strength of selection and influence mechanisms and quantify the relative contributions of homophile selection, assimilation to peers, and control mechanisms to observed similarity of substance use among friends.

sec.title: Appartenances multiples - Opinion plurielle
sec.p: Alexis Ferrand, Appartenances multiples - Opinion plurielle (2011, Lille: Presses du Septentrion, ISBN 978 2 7574 0209 2, 162 pp.). Un acteur qui exprime des jugements contradictoires est considéré comme incohérent. L’ouvrage propose un modèle sociologique de l’opinion plurielle qui explique la cohérence relationnelle de cette versatilité en combinant les paradigmes classiques de la multi-appartenance et de l’interactionnisme symbolique.

En situation d’incertitude, les acteurs se forment une opinion dans des relations de discussion, qui, au sein des réseaux, peuvent produire des opinons hétérogènes. Ce modèle implique une méthodologie capable : (a) d’enregistrer pour un enquêté des opinions divergentes sur le même problème ; (b) de relier chaque opinion aux relations de discussion qui l’ont faite émerger ; (c) d’observer comment ces relations sont hiérarchisées dans le réseau personnel. Finalement, ce modèle conduit à une transformation des modèles de diffusion.

La présentation de recherches sur des réseaux sociaux (discussion sur la santé, le cancer, le sida, des équipements publics) met en lumière les apports et limites des enquêtes habituelles, ainsi que des possibilités nouvelles.

Alexis Ferrand, est un enseignant à Grenoble, détaché au CNRS (pour l’enquête sur les comportements sexuels, ACSF) et professeur à Lille. Il étudie les réseaux de relations personnelles depuis le début des années 1980. Il a conduit des recherches sur les effets normatifs et cognitifs des relations de discussion sur la sexualité, le cancer et le sida. Il est membre du CNRS CLERSE, Université Lille 1.

Ce livre comprend sept chapitre : 1. Introduction – Relations et opinions (3-12) ; 2. Héritages théoriques et reformulations (13-36) ; 3. Des exemples d'explication du pluralisme cognitif par des interactions (37-48) ; 4. Appartenances multiples, opinion unique (49-102) ; 5. Appartenances multiples, opinion plurielle (103-114) ; 6. Expliquer l'opinion plurielle (115-140) ; 7. Conclusion (141-150).

Diana C. Mutz, Population-Based Survey Experiments (2011, Princeton University Press, ISBN 978 0 691 14452 8, 192 pp.). Population-based survey experiments have become an invaluable tool for social scientists struggling to generalize laboratory-based results, and for survey researchers besieged by uncertainties about causality. Thanks to technological advances in recent years, experiments can now be administered to random samples of the population to which a theory applies. Yet until now, there was no self-contained resource for social scientists seeking a concise and accessible overview of this methodology, its strengths and weaknesses, and the unique challenges it poses for implementation and analysis. Drawing on examples from across the social sciences, this book covers what one needs to know to plan, implement, and analyze the results of population-based survey experiments. It challenges conventional wisdom about internal and external validity, showing why strong causal claims need not come at the expense of external validity, and how it is now possible to execute experiments remotely using large-scale population samples. Its nine chapters are: 1. Population-Based Survey Experiments - A Hybrid Methodology for the Social Sciences; 2. Treatments to Improve Measurement; 3. Direct and Indirect Treatments; 4. Vignette Treatments; 5. Treatments in the Context of Games; 6. Execution of Population-Based Survey Experiments; 7. Analysis of Population-Based Survey Experiments; 8. External Validity Reconsidered; 9. More Than Just Another Method.

Melinda Mills, Introducing Survival and Event History Analysis (2011, Sage Publications, ISBN 978 1 84860 102 4, 288 pp.). This book is an accessible, practical and comprehensive guide for researchers and students who want to understand the basics of survival and event history analysis and apply these methods without getting entangled in mathematical and theoretical technicalities. Readers are offered a blueprint for their entire research project from data preparation to model selection and diagnostics. It covers the up-to-date innovations in the field, including advancements in the assessment of model fit, frailty and recurrent event models, discrete-time methods, competing and multi-state models and sequence analysis. Practical instructions are also included, focusing on the statistical program R and Stata, enabling readers to replicate the examples described in the text.

Lucinda Platt, Understanding Inequalities: Stratification and Difference (2011, Polity, ISBN 978 0 7456 4175 1, 204 pp.). While treating the core sociological topics of class, ethnicity and gender, this book examines how inequalities are experienced across a variety of settings, including education, health, geography and housing, income and wealth, and how they cumulate across the life course. It pays attention to how we know what we know about inequality: what is measured and how, what is left out of the picture, and what implications this has for our understanding of specific inequalities. The book also highlights the intersections between different sources or forms of inequality, and the ways that bringing multiple perspectives to bear on topics can highlight and challenge the assumptions about how they operate. It is designed for second-year undergraduates and above, and provides an engaging overview of social stratification and how inequalities are embedded across society. The major chapters cover (2) Class, (3) Gender, (4) Ethnicity, (5) Youth and Age, (6) Education, (7) Income, Wealth and Poverty, (8) Health and Disability, and (9) Housing and Geography.

J. Patrick Williams, Subcultural Theory - Traditions and Concepts (2011, Polity, ISBN 978 0 7456 4388 5, 214 pp.). Research into subcultural phenomena has spanned the humanities and social sciences, and the subcultural theories that underlie this work are similarly interdisciplinary. This work brings these diverse analytic issues together with a concise discussion of the major concepts and debates that have developed over more than eighty years of subcultural research, including style, resistance, deviance, identity, space, and media. The text emphasizes methods, concepts and analysis rather than mere descriptions of individual subcultures. Major chapters cover (1) Subcultural Theory, (2) Theoretical and Methodological Traditions, (3) Race and Gender in Subcultural Experience, and (7) Identity and Authenticity.

Francesco Duina, Institutions and the Economy (2011, Polity, ISBN 978 0 7456 4830 0, 206 pp.). This book examines the role of institutions – defined as the formal and informal rules and practices that surround us as we go about our daily lives – in the economy. Complex ideas are presented with carefully selected examples, and the investigation focuses on economic activity as it unfolds at the individual, organizational, national, and international levels.

John C. Bailar III and David C. Hoaglin (eds), Medical Uses of Statistics, Third Edition (2009, Wiley, ISBN: 978 0 470 43952 4, 491 pp.). While many of the examples are medical, the concepts and methods are far more general. The book is focused on what readers need to know as they read about statistical material, and there are no theoretical discussions or computing formulas. Contents include chapters on: 1. Statistical Concepts Fundamental to Investigations; 2. Some Uses of Statistical Thinking; 3. Use of Statistical Analysis in the New England Journal of Medicine; 4. Randomized Trials and Other Parallel Comparisons of Treatment; 7. Biostatistics in Epidemiology: Design and Basic Analysis; 10. Linear Regression in Medical Research; 11. Statistical Analysis of Survival Data; 16. Writing about Numbers; 18. Biostatistics in Epidemiology: Advanced Methods of Regression Analysis.
